R¬≤  = Measures the reduction in "Error" with the regression = Proportion of variabtion around the mean (SSM) explained by the variables  *R¬≤ vs t-test p-value vs F-test p-value*  --------  *FITABILITY / EXPLANABILITY / HOW MUCH* R¬≤  = [ SS(mean) - SS(fit) ] / SS(mean) = % variation explained by the fitted line Ideally, R¬≤ = 1 = 100%  --------  *BELIEVABILITY / HOW TRUE / P-VALUE* 18:00 F  = Variation explained by fit / Remaining variation  = [ SS(mean) - SS(fit) ]/DoF / SS(fit)/DoF = [ SS(mean) - SS(fit) ] /(# parameters in the fitting equation - # mean parameters i.e. 1)  /  SS(fit) / (# data - # parameters in fit equation) = Variation explained by the extra parameters used in the fit / Remaining variation, not explained by the fit = Ratio of variation explained by the fitted line vs the residual variations including noise. text: 7:20 what R^2 means How much of the variance in the y data can be explained by taking the x data into account. Taking the x data into account here means shifting the line around which we measure the variance from just being a flat line in the middle of the y data to being the regression line with respect to x data. R^2 = (variance around flat line - variance around regression line) / variance around flat line  The higher R^2 is, means the variance around the regression line is lower and we have a better fit - stronger correlation between the variables  12:20 predicting variable based on two variables instead of one. Two variables on the z and x axis, the prediction is the y axis. In this case we fit a plane to the data not a line. The plane has 3 parameters.  13:30 we fit a plane 14:20 if the tail length variable in the z axis isn‚Äôt useful (doesn‚Äôt give a higher R^2) then the least squares method will give it a coefficient of 0. Equations with more parameters won‚Äôt make the sum of squares around the fit worse than an equation with fewer parameters. Least squares will make parameters that make R^2 around the fit worse have 0 coefficient. So having more parameters won‚Äôt make our r^2 worse, but it could make it better due to random chance. (Without there actually being a correlation)  15:50 we report an adjusted R^2 that scales R^2 by the number of params in the model  16:00 R^2 needs a p-value  Todo:- Continue isA
